newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan firms denies Oak patent charge.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan firms denies Oak patent charge.

text.p: Four Taiwan electronic companies on Thursday denied charges that they have infringed patents of U.S.-based Oak Technology Inc.

Oak said on Tuesday it had filed a complaint with the U.S. International Trade Commission against nine companies, alleging a violation of trade laws for importing and selling products that Oak believes infringe two of its patents.
Oak makes CD-ROM controllers used in computers.
Five of the nine firms are from Taiwan, including United Microelectronics, Winbond, Lite-on Group, Lite-On Technology, and Behavior Tech.
The first four firms denied the charges, while Behavior was not immediately available for comment.

"I'm very surprised by Oak's move because we and Oak have reconciled in the case," United Micro vice-president J.S. Aur told Reuters. "There must be some mistakes there, and I believe Oak will soon withdraw its charge against us."
Aur said United Micro produces only T$20 million worth of CD-ROM controllers a year, a small part of its 1996 sales of T$22.6 billion.
A Winbond spokesman, who declined to be named, said the firm was unlikely to have infringed Oak's patents.
"We contacted Oak in February, and the initial results showed that it's impossible we have infringed Oak's patents," the Winbond spokesman said by telephone.
"Still we have to wait for Oak's formal complaint documents, but it's unlikely we have infringed Oak's patents," he said.
Lite-On Technology and Lite-On Group said Oak's patent complaints would not affect its production and sales of CD-ROMs.
"We are surprised to be involved in this because we bought CD-ROM parts from United Micro to produce CD-ROMs," said Lite-On spokeswoman Kuo Hsiu-chuan.
"While United Micro told us that it had already reconciled with Oak, so we believe the case will be solved soon, and it should not affect our CD-ROM production and sales," Kuo said.
